Title:
The phylogenetic position of African Vitrinidae: old family
groups unravelled
Keywords:
Vitrinidae, molecular phylogeny, anatomy, Africa,
Macaronesia
Abstract:
A phylogenetic investigation comprising species of the
semi-slug family Vitrinidae from Europe, East Africa and Macaronesia is
presented. Two mitochondrial markers (COI & 16S) and a set of
nuclear markers (H3, ITS2 and 28S) were used in Maximum Likelihood (ML)
and Bayesian Inference (BI) analyses. The synopsis of molecular and
anatomical data provide a first insight into the phylogenetic
relationships of these groups. The existence of a split between
European, Macaronesian and African genera is proven. The direct
relationship between the Macaronesian group and described new East
African genus Sanettivitrina scripta nov. gen. nov. sp. as a relic of
this radiation is demonstrated. The separation of the other East African
Vitrinidae into two clades, viz.Â Arabivitrina Thiele, 1931 and
Calidivitrina Pilsbry, 1919, could not be confirmed. The hitherto used
morphologically-based generic definitions are not able to explain the
existence of at least five lineages. Apparently, the genital organs of
the Arabivitrina and Calidivitrina type developed several times in
parallel. There is evidence that the fully limacised family Limacidae
represents the sister taxon to the Vitrinidae.
